From https://support.atlassian.com/browse/CSP-80933
{quote}Is there some native way for getting a list of incoming links and referrers (incoming links from Jira 5) as a page element.
Currently these informations are just "metadata" in the page info which must be navigated and can't be exported as PDF etc.

Adaptavist seems to have some (partial) solutions but as far as I can see not covering the new Jira "Trackback pings".
https://www.adaptavist.com/display/AtlassianConfluence/incoming-links+macro

~Marcel
{quote}

{quote}
HengHwa Loi [Atlassian] added a comment - 07/May/12 5:24 AM
Hi Marcel,

To answer your original question:

I'm afraid no, there're no such feature in Confluence yet, the referrers is hard coded into the metadata page and I don't think there's a place to take that part out.
{quote}

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-25664].
  {panel}

some things that would make the gallery macro better:

the image attached to the page has a comment field.  when a comment is provided, it is used as both the caption for the photo in the gallery and for the tooltip that you get when hovering over the photo in the gallery.

but having the filename of the image would also be useful for example when the gallery has 300 images and you want to download the JPG from the attachments.

i'd suggest that the filename be placed into the tooltip regardless of whether the attachment comment is populated.

the gallery macro would benefit from a parameter that controls whether or not captions are shown.

then, if the comment is not populated, the filename be used as the caption.  if the comment field is there, it could take precedence over the filename as the caption.

in addition, it would be hugely helpful to be able to link from an image in the gallery.  not sure where that would go, except possibly on the comment field of the attachment.  

perhaps another gallery macro parameter could control whether the comment field is used for a URL or for a caption.  or if you detect a URL in the comment, make that the link for the gallery image rather than assuming we want to see the full size image when clicking.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-25659].
  {panel}

 While the editor is great, memory consumption on the browser side is unreasonably large in Chrome.  If the user only edits once or twice during the life of the browser process, then it's okay.  But if you're doing lots of content creation or editing, and therefore using the editor quite a bit, the memory consumption eventually becomes so great that system resources become an issue.

I can demonstrate this problem by going to any page and clicking Edit, then cancelling to leave the editor.  Each time I do this, my Chrome process grows fairly dramatically.   

In an effort to put some numbers around it, I did some testing and created a spreadsheet, and from that I created a chart (attached).   The chart illustrates memory consumption (in MB) on IE vs Chrome, for successive editing sessions of the exact same page (a simple page that fits "above the fold")

That exercise made me realize that the problem is not _quite_ as bad as I thought, because the memory consumption does seem to level off in Chrome on a simple test, in which the same page is being edited again and again.

It would take me more time than I have right now to do a comprehensive test of a more realistic scenario, but I can assure you that, when you're editing multiple pages, and using multiple browser windows or tabs, you eventually start to get some amazing memory consumption -- around half a GB for a single process.   This definitely becomes noticeable.  And I'm not talking about hundreds of pages over the course of many hours.  Just a dozen or so pages for an hour or two,  a fairly normal amount of work for an active editor.

The memory consumption in Chrome is spectacular enough that I was certain this issue would already exist in JIRA.  I looked for one pretty hard, but did not find one.  If this turns out to be a duplicate, I apologize.
fields.summary: Significant Memory Consumption in Chrome while Editing

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-25624].
  {panel}

When you have a conflict in the Confluence editor, the screen includes a complete diff of the changes, a warning box as well as the editor. The layout is completely broken, and the reduction in the height of the editor and the fact that the content can expand larger than the screen makes it basically impossible to use, even on a really large screen.

We've still got the old way the editor UI worked, but that doesn't really work any more. The old UI didn't have a limited height for the edit page, so the diff appeared in full and it just pushed the editor down. The current situation with a tiny area to view the diff and a restricted edit height is a big problem.

See attached screenshot.

We need to do something better than this, but I'm not sure exactly what. Perhaps we could display the diff in a dialog when the user clicks a button, rather than putting it in the page directly.
fields.summary: Editor conflict screen is laid out badly, very hard to use

These do not indicate a problem, so we should remove them.

The cause of this issue is that the aui-staging plugin is not available in the setup plugin system. The setup decorator, {{setup.vmd}}, has the following line:

{noformat}
    #requireResource("com.atlassian.auiplugin:ajs")
{noformat}

This resource has a dependency on the {{confluence.aui.staging}} modules:

{noformat}
        <!-- Resources that are in the process of being added to AUI -->
        <dependency>confluence.aui.staging:meta</dependency>
        <dependency>confluence.aui.staging:dark-features</dependency>
        <dependency>confluence.aui.staging:storage-manager</dependency>
{noformat}

We need to either load this plugin in the setup bundled plugins library, or move these dependencies elsewhere.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-25556].
  {panel}

If you attach an outdated database to a newer Confluence instance (app + home directory) the upgrade tasks don't get run.

This is because the com.atlassian.confluence.upgrade.AbstractUpgradeManager.needUpgrade() check will pass, since the WEB-INF/lib/confluence-<version>.jar:com/atlassian/confluence/default.properties:build.number equals the build number from the confluence.cfg.xml:buildNumber element in the home directory.

There is a com.atlassian.confluence.upgrade.impl.DefaultUpgradeManager.getDatabaseBuildNumber() which is a _select max(BUILDNUMBER) from CONFVERSION_. As far as I can see this is only used to decide to run DatabaseUpgradeTasks (_com.atlassian.confluence.upgrade.AbstractUpgradeManager.executeUpgradeStep(List<UpgradeTask>, UpgradeStep)_).

Using the database build number for a sanity check would be unsatisfactory since it is only set after a specific task is run, so I guess we need an additional place for that.
fields.summary: Add a sanity check for preventing the usage of an outdated database with a newer home directory / webapp

fields.description:
The fix for CONF-22132 was not sufficient because "svg" files are not "said" to be xml by the isXml() method. This means that is possible for a malicious party to upload a svg file containing html/javascript which will be rendered in victim's web browser. 

This bug should have been raised a while ago, but it seems that it was forgotten ... (history: In CONF-23171 I included the following comment "(Hmm and it seems I did not report the svg bug in confluence yet - see JRA-24854) ". )
We should fix this soon because in CONF-1762 there are public comments basically pointing out this persistent xss flaw.


Steps to reproduce:
1. create a file called "foo.svg" with the following contents:

<html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" xml:lang="en">
<script>alert(3);</script>
</html>

2. upload it to confluence
3. 'view' the attachment 
4. see an alert dialogue with the number 3 in it.
fields.summary: persistent xss through svg file attachment download

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-25464].
  {panel}

The editor in 4.2.2 (probably was introduced earlier but our company is just upgrading to 4.x) takes up an excessive amount of vertical space.  I'm calling this a bug since I think it’s a bad UX design and should have been thought through.

The title bar, toolbar and lower tool/info bar take up about 250 pixels combined.  On a screen where your browser leaves you with 875 vertical pixels of space, the controls for the editor are taking almost 30% of the usable region!!

The  title bar is especially excessive.  Its uses unnecessarily huge font text.  It should be made smaller so that more room can be left for editable region.

Some improvements / specific issues:
* Make the title bar a regular size one-line text region (no formatting)
* Once a table has been added to the document, the table controls in the toolbar are always displayed even if your cursor is not contextually inside of the table.
* The upper and lower toolbars have a lot of padding above and below the buttons.  This should be reduced to 1-2 pixels.
* The "Hint / Last Edited" bar should be made optional.  
** Ideally combine the last saved information to the lower toolbar (maybe just add a simple time in the "save" button such as "Save (8:14a)"
** Make the hint info completely optional
* Give user choice of having small toolbar buttons that take up less space
* Either give the user or the Space Admin option to customize the buttons that appear in the toolbar
* Move the lower toolbar into the upper toolbar and change the buttons to standard toolbar buttons w/o labels. 
** If you feel its needed you can still offer a pref to have toolbar buttons shown with text or not.  
** Some apps have a nice 3rd state which shows text on only the buttons which are really deserving of more than a simple icon.

The design of the editor as it stands now is form over function!!  I hope that the developers see to making changes to make this app more geared to getting work done efficiently instead of fussing over making sure the UI looks "pretty".  

Use case (to demonstrate how the current design impedes):
As it stands now, if I'm writing a spec and I paste an screenshot in that is 600 pixels high, I don't have any room to view the image and type about it.  All I need is about 10 lines below the image but now I'm forced to open a new window to preview the image while I type.

btw: I do like how some of the toolbar buttons where combined into multi-function to save space like having the 'insert' and different html controls under that.
fields.summary: Improve editor vertical height usage, especially for smaller screens

Hi, I have a customer is complaining regarding the [Application Links|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Integrating+JIRA+and+Confluence] is outdated, and part of the information is not available anymore, or deprecated.

Here are the suggestions on what to updates:

- would it not be better to describe the way to use the new Jira 5 remote links including full-text search for Confluence pages instead of still promoting the Jira Linker community plugin?
- shortcuts still work but they do not seem to insert a "mentioned by Confluence page" link into the linked Jira issue; it seems to me that this way of linking should be discouraged
- Insert Jira Issue on the other hand inserts this link but that is not mentioned anywhere in the Confluence help as far as I can see
- also the mentioned by x link above seems to work without enabling Tracebacks, so are tracebacks still working with Jira or not? I could not get this to work at all; nor do I see any current way to get a mentioned by Jira issue link in a Confluence page, it only works the other way round
- the whole paragraph "Applinks Plugin" seems to be outdated; I believe this is the actual Application Link feature; but inserting a Confluence page into a Jira issue via [page name] does not create a hotlink; is this now replaced by remote links?
- activity streams seem to be combined out of the box on a global level but for the project - space level it seems to be important to link project and space together; this is not mentioned in the two pages
fields.summary: Need Update On Application Links Documentation

* [Gallery Macro|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Gallery+Macro]
